pros: Co-workers and supervisors are always friendly, and versatile in their knowledge base. Students have very reliable, and prompt one on one appointments with staff. If you like working in a university that's quick to travel between campus buildings, and with class sizes comparable to community college size classrooms and offices as opposed to a large auditorium then you would enjoy working here.
cons: The university is on a hill. It only takes about 5 - 7 minutes to walk up the hill from street level, but disabled students and/or staff using wheelchairs that are manual as opposed to motorized might have a bit of a challenge getting up the driveway on the hill. So, they may need to make arrangements with the public safety office or an agency like Ready Wheels to take them up the hill.

pros: People, culture, mission and values, students
cons: Management was a disaster, especially the financial leadership

review_title: Poor leadership and opaque decision making
pros: Many staff members at NDNU are helpful, kind, and professional. This is doubly impressive considering working here is awful, entire departments have been let go, basic services, like HR and IT and Marketing, have been completely outsourced. And this with no input/fdbk discussion with staff
cons:
Decision making is secretive and opaque. Decisions impacting everyone are made with no input from staff. A group of 3-5 ppl make all decisions. 
There is always talk of change and it’ll get better once enrollments grow. But NDNU tried to close, changed their minds and said they’d transition to a grad only uni and that is failing. 
No camaraderie or collegial trust or culture.

pros: work hours, benefits, holidays, coworkers
cons: unrealistic goals, people at top do not know what they are doing, hostile and toxic work environment

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Belmont, CA
pros: The base salary is competitive in comparison to other colleges.
cons: There are no raises and promotions are uncommon.

pros: Faith based great students there
cons: High demands, stress, salary, etc.

pros: Small campus - intimate community of students, professors, staff, and alums
cons: Small campus - not enough qualified people

pros: First generation college students attending
cons: Misappropriation of Funding - closed due to mismanagement

review_title: Higher Education is what it is
job_title: Residence Life Coordinator in Belmont, CA
pros: Its great to mentor and work with students
cons: Higher education careers don't typically pay well. Especially when they are Private universities struggling to meet enrollment goals

pros:
+1 star for the people and community - a lot of passion and student-centered 
+1 star for the students - the values of social justice and service are pinnacle for many
cons:
-1 star for the management/turnover - poor communicators, ineffective leaders and terrible at judging morale. You're constantly getting a new supervisor and a new team because of turnover.
-1 star for the retention/enrollment/budget woes - this school not only struggles to keep their students but also to recruit new ones. This adds pressure to all departments to try to keep functioning at the same or better capacity with less resources. 
-1 star for being underpaid, overworked and under-appreciated - they expect miracles with a shoestring budget. Don't expect your paycheck to keep pace with the cost of living.

The values and mission appeal to many but, unfortunately, it's all talk and little walk and even the students see that.

review_title: Public Safety Not recommended: Poor management
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Belmont, CA
pros: Great benefits. Small campus. Small staff so there is more direct contact with the various departments. Can be a help to students and staff members on campus. Grateful that I got this experience so far to transfer to a regular police department.
cons: Unexperienced and non-courteous staff (even on things like basic etiquette. The main issue is that the newly hired department that still isn't quite up to the task and needs to be purged and hire more experienced officers. This place has a high turnover so be expected to be threatened with your job within those first six months of hire. The pay is low for the position   as well.

pros: Paid winter break, a very few nice employees, reasonable work hours, can go to school for free after six months. That's it.
cons:
Poor morale. Managers/Departments act as if they like each other but openly discuss how much they hate one another to the employees of their department. Faculty and staff do not get along or communicate. The pay is below average and there is no room to grow. Issues within departments are never resolved and the employee is the one to leave because HR, directors, and VPs to do like to get involved. Employees are afraid to ask for time off because managers throw a fit. Unpaid overtime.
Managers show favoritism towards a few staff members and students. There is favoritism towards student athletes which some departments have been know to bend certain rules and policies for.

pros: Smart and hardworking colleagues. The location is beautiful, a natural environment within a city and on the northern end of Silicon Valley. Good work/life balance.
cons: There are good and bad elements of benefits. The medical plan is costly if you insure family members or partners. Time off is generous. Salary/pay is low for the region. There are faculty who feel entitled to higher pay and share negative attitudes because of it.

review_title: Spiritual, committed, fulfilling, I loved working here and blessed to have been around such wonderful people.
pros: Good benefits, lots of positive reinforcement, and surrounded by people who appreciate higher education, and nature.
cons: With all educational institutions, is lack of funds,  you have to work here for the passion of what it is your seeking.

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Mateo, CA
pros: Students are great and a blast to work with them in all of the classes. They want the best education and they should get it.
cons: Management not so good and I don't think they really care about the teaching staff. many abuses in scheduling too many students per class.

pros:
Incredibly caring staff and supportive work environment. 
Management truly cares about the students and the faculty/staff.
Terrific work/life balance
cons:
Mediocre dental plan
Small percentage of vocal, adversarial faculty who refuse to do anything new or out of the box and drag their grievances into their classrooms.
Money issues due to being a small private

pros: Good mission and values. Great people. Nice environment.
cons: Understaffed, overworked and underpaid staff. Senior administration unaware or ignore staff challenges. Faculty and staff are disconnected.

pros: Great faculty, sincere students who stuck because most courses wont transfer out
cons: management is ungrateful, sloppy dress code, unprofessional HR

pros: Tight community of staff and faculty; social justice mission; low-key, hard working, committed staff.
cons: Communication and coordination throughout the levels of the university is a challenge, and effects the worker's experience.

pros: people are nice, campus is lovely, and professors are good
cons: departments don't get along, communication is hard, people openly don't like their job

pros: A small University so people a close community feeling is there.
cons: Pay could be better for faculty and staff.

review_title: Working At A University is Acceptable, For A While.
pros:
Friendly and welcoming staff.
Understanding of situations.
cons:
Under appreciated at times.
No growth.

pros: Great professors, small class sizes, beautiful campus, location
cons: Financial woes, pay is on the low end

pros: Community feels like family, can acquire education for free
cons: The pay is lower than market rate.

pros: Mission, Engaged Faculty, Committed Staff
cons: Limited finances potentially impact long term future

pros: Small size campus allows for continuous contact with fellow peers.
cons: Small private school receives minimal funding
